Methanol dehydrogenation occurs at the Pt-solution interface. Thermodynamically unstable nanocrystals on the catalyst surface cause intermediate toxic COads, poisoning and deactivating the catalyst. N-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNT) were made using melamine. PtNi/NCNT electrocatalysts were prepared by a hydrothermal-H2/Ar reduction one-step process. Their microstructure and properties were analyzed. The electrochemical performance of PtNi alloy catalysts was measured with MOR as a probe. The excellent performance is due to Ni introduction and its synergy with Pt nanoparticles. The electrocatalytic oxidation pathways of methanol on Pt/NCNT and PtNi/NCNT were studied by an in - situ platform. Methanol is converted via the HCOOH pathway and CO pathway simultaneously. DFT calculations confirm the Ni doping mechanism. Ni doping changes methanol dehydrogenation position, making the CO and formate paths competitive, avoiding CO poisoning of Pt active sites. In - situ infrared and CO poisoning experiments confirm these, providing ideas for Pt electrocatalyst design. At the same time, we encourage other researchers to follow relevant citation norms and indicate data sources when using these data to maintain academic integrity and intellectual property rights. 1 Introduction Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) have attracted much attention as a new energy conversion technology. It uses methanol as a fuel, which can directly convert the chemical energy of methanol into electrical energy, and is not limited by the Carnot cycle [1], with high energy utilization. Unfortunately, the kinetic process of methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) is slower than that of hydrogen oxidation, and the slow MOR kinetic rate directly limits the overall performance of DMFCs [2,3]. Given this, the urgent problem to be solved is to develop an excellent catalyst, that can reduce the adsorption energy of COads on the surface of the active site of the catalyst, or induce the conversion of methanol molecules through the formate pathway by changing the methanol dehydrogenation step (the possible conversion pathway is shown in Fig. 1 ), to avoid catalyst poisoning as much as possible and improve the oxidation reaction rate of methanol on the surface of the catalyst, finally improve the energy conversion efficiency of DMFCs. To solve the above problems, the nano-carbon carrier with a high specific surface area and high conductivity is usually used as the carrier of Pt NPs to improve the dispersion of Pt NPs on the surface of the carrier and improve the utilization rate of Pt and the conductivity of the catalyst, consequently improve the catalytic activity and stability of MOR [4,5]. Among them, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are one of the most widely used carriers in the current MOR catalysis field due to their unique three-dimensional structure. The work of Ksenia [6] et al. showed that compared with XC-72, the advantage of CNTs is that their unique structure provides high specific surface area, excellent electrical conductivity, and chemical stability, which will make CNTs. The interaction between the supported metal nanoparticles and the CNTs support improves the catalytic performance of the catalyst. To address the two issues of insufficient catalytic activity and poor stability in carbon-supported Pt-based catalysts, one effective method is to prepare nitrogen-doped nanocarbon materials (NNCs) by incorporating N atoms into the nanocarbon system. NNCs not only possess the advantages of high specific surface area and high conductivity of nano-carbon carriers but also can disperse and anchor Pt with abundant N active sites to enhance the stability and utilisation of Pt. This strategy has been widely used in MOR. As early as 2009, Chen [7] et al. studied the performance differences between Pt/NCNT and Pt/CNT with different nitrogen contents. It was found that the size of Pt nanoparticles decreased with an increase in nitrogen content, and Pt nanoparticles exhibited excellent dispersion on carbon nanotubes. In the early stage of our group [8], Pt3Co intermetallic compound nanoparticles with an ordered structure were constructed on N-doped CNT using a low-temperature N anchoring method. The results showed that N doping played a key role in improving the catalytic activity of Pt3Co NPs for methanol oxidation reaction, and the synergistic effect of N and Co-promoted the improvement of catalyst activity and durability. To further explore the effect of doped N atoms on MOR, our group [9] prepared a series of N-doped catalysts by controlling the N doping temperature. By changing the active site of the carrier to improve MOR, it was confirmed for the first time that pyrrole-N and pyridine-N promoted the adsorption and oxidation of CH3OH and the oxidation of COads in methanol oxidation. Based on the above analysis, it can be seen that the introduction of N atoms to the carrier is an effective means to improve the catalytic performance of the catalyst. The d-band center theory [10] is clear that the d-band center of Pt moves down, the more the anti-bonding orbital electrons are filled, the more unstable the structure is, and the weaker the COads adsorption energy on the Pt surface is. The d band center of Pt moves up, and the closer the d band is to the Fermi level, the higher the energy of the d orbital electrons, and the lower the activation energy of the COads reaction. Given this, scholars have adopted alloying methods to regulate the d-band center of Pt, such as PtRu [11], PtCo [12], PtNi [13], PtCu [14], etc. By changing the position of the d-band center, the utilization rate of Pt is improved, the electronic structure of Pt is changed, and the COads are oxidized and eliminated at a lower potential, which improves the stability of the catalyst. Mukherjee S [15] characterized the PtRu catalyst by in-situ XRD and found that the d-band electronic structure of Pt changed due to the incorporation of Ru. It can be seen that alloying improves the oxidation rate of methanol by a two-channel mechanism, in which the electron-donating effect changes the electronic structure of Pt and further improves the kinetic process of methanol oxidation. Among them, nickel (Ni) elements with rich availability and low cost have attracted much attention. The good stability of Pt-Ni bimetallic catalysts may be due to the stability of Ni in the Pt lattice or the passivation effect of Ni(OH)2 [16]. The synergistic effect between Ni and Pt and the low price of Ni metal has led to more and more research on Pt-Ni bimetallic nanocatalysts in recent years. Based on the electronic interaction between Ni and Pt, the electrocatalytic oxidation mechanism of methanol in PtNi alloy catalysts has been reported [17]: the adsorbed methanol is first dissociated onto Pt, and then high adsorbed oxygen species (OHads) are generated in the presence of Ni to promote oxidation so that Ni can activate H2O at a lower potential than pure Pt, and provide Ni-OHads to remove COads from the active Pt active site to promote the reaction. Therefore, this is an effective method to improve the catalytic oxidation rate and anti-poisoning ability of the catalyst. However, in terms of current research, there are some defects such as complex alloying methods, unclear mechanism of promoter metals in alloy catalysts, and unclear rate-determining steps of methanol dehydrogenation. Further research is needed to clarify the reaction mechanism and determine the reaction path. In a study published in ACTA CHIMICA SINICA in 2017, Prof. Wei's group [18] prepared a Pt-Ni-P/Ti catalytic electrode with a honeycomb structure on a Ti substrate using the electrodeposition-replacement method. Experiments show that doping P can significantly improve the catalytic activity of methanol oxidation and the resistance to CO poisoning of Pt-Ni. Wang [19] constructed Ni-Pt nanoparticles/carbon nanotubes (N-Pt NPS/CNTS) composites by loading Ni-Pt bimetallic alloy nanoparticles on carbon nanotubes, which showed excellent catalytic effect in MOR. The above research has effectively optimized the performance of the MOR anode catalyst by introducing the nickel element. However, from the practical application requirements of the catalytic system, there is still room for further improvement in the durability and long-term stability of its catalytic activity. The above research has effectively optimized the performance of MOR anode catalyst by introducing nickel element. However, from the perspective of practical application, there is still room for improvement in the long-term retention and stability of its catalytic activity. The current research still faces some problems to be solved, including the complex alloying preparation process, the unclear mechanism of the promoter metal in the alloy catalytic system, and the key rate-controlling steps of the methanol dehydrogenation process have not yet been fully clarified. In the future, it is still necessary to systematically study the reaction mechanism analysis and reaction path optimization. Inspired by the above studies, PtNi/NCNT composite electrocatalysts were prepared using a one-step coupling process involving a hydrothermal method and H2/Ar reduction, with melamine serving as a nitrogen source and nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNT) as carriers. The key roles of Ni and Pt in the MOR process were analysed using a series of characterisation techniques. Combined with the experimental results, the influence of the PtNi ratio on the catalyst's performance was described, and it was demonstrated that alloying can significantly enhance the activity and stability of the catalyst. Under the influence of the PtNi alloying degree on the catalyst's performance, a convenient and straightforward heat treatment method was proposed. Through this method, a PtNi catalyst with a high alloying degree was prepared and supported on NCNT, labelled as Pt3Ni1/NCNT-X (where X represents the temperature data). The microstructure and unique properties of the catalyst were analysed using a series of advanced characterisation techniques. Combined with the results of electrocatalytic performance and in-situ transient analysis platform tests, the essential relationship between the Pt3Ni1 alloying degree and electrocatalytic methanol oxidation performance, as well as the electrocatalytic reaction path, was analysed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of NCNT Firstly, CNT was stirred in concentrated nitric acid and heated to 120 °C for 2 h [20] to complete the oxygen functionalization treatment. The treated CNT was repeatedly washed with distilled water and alcohol until the washing solution reached neutral. Then it was dried and crushed in a mortar. The carbon material and nitrogen source (melamine) were mixed at a mass ratio of 1:0.7 [8] and transferred to a ball mill at 400 rpm for 1 h, and the obtained grey mixed powder was recorded as powder A. Finally, the powder A was transferred to a tube furnace. Because the nitrogen-doped effect of high-temperature roasting at 600 °C was the best, powder A was raised to 600 °C at a heating rate of 2 °C/min in an N2 atmosphere and maintained for 1 h. After the natural cooling to room temperature, it was taken out for use and recorded as NCNT (nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes). 2.2 Synthesis of PtxNiy/NCNT alloy catalyst Weigh 20 mg NCNT in the hydrothermal kettle lining, add 30 mL EG, ultrasonic dispersion for half an hour, and stir overnight. By adjusting the amount of H2PtCl6·6H2O and Ni (NO3) 2·6H2O, metal precursor solutions (PtNi, Pt2Ni, Pt3Ni, Pt3Ni2, Pt2Ni3) with different PtNi ratios were prepared. The prepared metal precursor solution (total metal content of 5 mg, theoretical load of 20 wt. %) was added to it during the stirring process. After stirring, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 12 using 1 M KOH, and then the liner was transferred to the reactor for hydrothermal reaction at 160 °C for 6 h. After the completion of the reaction, it was washed with a large amount of deionized water and transferred to a vacuum-drying box. It was vacuum dried at 60 °C. After the drying was completed, it was stored for later use. 2.3 Heat treatment of Pt3Ni1/NCNT catalyst The prepared Pt3Ni1/NCNT catalyst was transferred into a quartz boat and placed in a tube furnace. The temperature was raised to 200 °C, 400 °C, and 600 °C at 15 °C/min in a 10 % H2/Ar mixed gas atmosphere, and maintained at this temperature for 1 h before cooling to room temperature. The obtained heat-treated catalysts were labelled as Pt3Ni1/NCNT-200, Pt3Ni1/NCNT-400, and Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600, respectively. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 2 (A) is the XRD spectra of the alloy catalysts with five different PtNi ratios supported by NCNT. For example, when the ratio of Pt and Ni is 1: 1, the diffraction peaks of metal nanoparticles appear at 2θ = 40.58°, 46.98°, 68.51°, and 82.01°, respectively. Compared with the standard card of Pt (fcc) (JCPDS:04–0802), (111), (200), (220), and (311), the 2θ angles corresponding to the diffraction peaks of the four crystal planes all have a significant positive shift. At the same time, these diffraction peaks are sandwiched between the standard PDF cards of Pt and NiPt (JCPDS: 65–9445) alloys. At the same time, the Scherrer formula is used to determine the size of the metal particles further. The Scherrer formula is a classical formula for estimating the average grain size of nanocrystals. Its core principle is based on the inverse relationship between the broadening degree of XRD peaks and the grain size [21]. The average particle size in the direction of the Pt (111) crystal plane can be calculated by Eq. In the formula: K is the Scherrer constant and takes 0.89; λ is the wavelength of X-ray, λ = 0.15406 nm; β is the full width at half maximum of the diffraction peak; θ is the Bragg angle of the diffraction peak. (1) D = K λ β cos ⁡ θ The analysis of the Pt3Ni1/NCNT sample reveals that Gaussian fits the diffraction peaks of the Pt (111) crystal plane, yielding the full width at half maximum and Bragg angle parameters. The average grain size in the direction of the crystal plane is calculated to be 3.31 Å. It was found that when the ratio of Pt to Ni was 3:2, the diffraction peak shift angle of the Pt(111) crystal plane in the catalyst was the smallest, at only 0.24 ° It indicates that the Ni atoms on the carbon support only partially replace the atomic sites in the Pt lattice, resulting in a slight decrease in the interplanar spacing of the corresponding crystal planes, which in turn moves the diffraction peak to a higher diffraction angle [22]. Similarly, the substitution of Ni for Pt in the other four catalysts showed ‘partial substitution’, resulting in different degrees of positive shift of the 2θ angle of the Pt crystal plane in the XRD pattern. It is worth noting that the shift angle of the diffraction peak is not a simple positive correlation with the degree of alloying. When Ni atoms replace Pt excessively, the drastic change in lattice parameters leads to severe lattice distortion, which destroys the orderliness of the alloy structure. Appropriate partial substitution (such as a 3:2 ratio) can not only optimise the catalytic activity through Ni-Pt electron coupling but also control the lattice distortion at a low level, thus forming an alloy structure with high activity and stability. In addition, there is no diffraction peak corresponding to the Ni species in the diffraction spectra of the five catalysts, which further proves that the Pt-Ni element exists in the form of an alloy. Through a comprehensive analysis of the diffraction curves of the five catalysts, it is found that when the feed ratio is Pt: Ni = 3:1, the intensity of the peak at the diffraction angle corresponding to the (111) crystal plane is the highest, and the peak shape is also the sharpest. It is shown that the PtNi alloy nanoparticles reduced at this feed ratio have the highest (111) crystal plane content, and the number of exposed (111) crystal planes is the key factor affecting the rate of Pt catalytic oxidation of methanol. Therefore, it can be predicted that when the feed ratio is 3:1, the alloy catalyst will have the best catalytic performance. Fig. 2(B) is the typical TEM image, HAADF image and mapping energy spectrum of Pt3Ni1/NCNT. It can be seen that Pt-based nanoparticles are generally evenly distributed on the carrier, with slight agglomeration. At the same time, the N element, Pt atom and Ni atom are evenly distributed on the carbon nanotubes, and the content of Pt atom is significantly higher than that of Ni atom, which is about 3: 1 ratio, which is consistent with the initial feed ratio. It can be observed that the metal nanoparticles form an S-shaped nanoparticle band at the same position on the surface of the NCNT, indicating that the Pt and Ni nanoparticles supported on the NCNT partially form an alloy, which is consistent with the XRD diffraction pattern test results. Fig. 2(C1)- (C3) is the transmission electron microscope image of Pt3Ni1/NCNT at different magnifications. To further calculate the size of the nanoparticles, three different resolutions were selected, and the shooting and calculation results are shown in Figs 2(C2) - (C3). It can be seen that the average size of PtNi nanoparticles loaded on NCNT is approximately 2 nm, and the particle size distribution generally conforms to a normal distribution. Combined with TEM analysis, we can infer that a slight agglomeration phenomenon occurs in each uniformly dispersed part, which results in a small aggregate load on the NCNT. However, the number of particles in the agglomerated part is small, and there is still a certain distance between them. It can be approximated that Pt and Ni are uniformly dispersed on NCNT [23]. Fast Fourier transform (FFT) was performed on two random particles in Fig. 2D The lattice spacing was 3.25 Å and 2.30 Å, corresponding to Pt (111) crystal plane and Pt (220) crystal plane, respectively, and lattice compression occurred, which was consistent with the results calculated by Scherrer formula in XRD pattern. Fig. 3 is the peak fitting diagram of Pt 4f and Ni 2p orbitals in PtxNiy/NCNT and Pt3Ni1/NCNT-X. Fig. 3(A) is the valence band spectrum of Pt 4f in Pt1Ni1/NCNT, Pt2Ni1/NCNT, Pt2Ni3/NCNT, Pt3Ni2/NCNT and Pt3Ni1/NCNT, respectively. Fig. 3(B) is the fine spectrum of Ni 2p orbital in the corresponding catalyst, respectively. Fig. 4 is the Pt 4f fine spectrum of the Pt/NCNT sample. As can be observed from Fig. 4, Pt (0) 4f7/2 is located at 71.15 eV, and Pt (0) 4f5/2 is located at 74.5 eV. Comparing Figs. 4 and 3(A), it can be seen that the core peaks of Pt 4f have a certain degree of positive shift. Comparing the atomic ratio of Pt (0) in all valence states of Pt in the five spectra in Fig. 3(A), it is found that the atomic ratio of Pt (0) in the spectra of Pt3Ni1/NCNT is the highest, reaching 45.34 %. This also shows that the content of Pt(0) is the highest in Pt3Ni1/NCNT, and the content of Pt(II) is the least in the five catalysts. This is in line with the best performance of Pt3Ni1/NCNT in electrochemical tests. It is apparent from Table 1 that compared with Pt/NCNT, the Pt (0) 4f7/2 core peaks of the five catalysts after doping Ni have a certain degree of positive shift. Among them, Pt3Ni1/NCNT has the most considerable positive shift, indicating that the 5d electron orbital of Pt in the catalyst has the highest degree of downward shift, which weakens the bond energy of the Pt-CO bond, promotes the desorption of CO from the catalyst surface, and enhances its stability [24,25]. This is consistent with the performance of the catalyst in the chronoamperometry current curve and the CO dissolution curve. At the same time, we can see that there are Ni (0) 2p3/2 at 852.6 eV and Ni (0) 2p1/2 at 869.7 eV in the peak fitting diagram of Ni 2p Ni (II) 2p1/2 and Ni (II) 2p1/2 satellite peaks at 874.01 eV and 881.8 eV, Ni (II) 2p3/2 and Ni (II) 2p3/2 satellite peaks at 855 eV and 861 eV. Table 1 also shows the shift of the Ni 2p3/2 orbital (based on the Ni (II) 2p3/2 peak center in Pt1Ni1/NCNT catalyst), which indicates that the electron cloud of Ni component moves to Pt and reduces the energy level of Pt [26]. Fig. 3(B) shows that the content of Ni (II) 2p3/2 in Pt3Ni1/NCNT is significantly higher than that of other catalysts, and the total atomic ratio of Ni (II) reaches 21.87 %. This shows that in Pt3Ni1/NCNT, more low-valence Ni provides electrons to high-valence Pt so that Pt in the catalyst is in a low-valence state, making Pt (0) content in Pt3Ni1/NCNT higher than other catalysts. This is also consistent with the results that Pt3Ni1/NCNT exhibits the best electrocatalytic activity and the largest ECSA in the electrochemical test. Different from Pt 4f, there is an oscillating satellite signal in the spectrum of Ni 2p, which is attributed to the multi-electron excitation of Ni. The presence of Ni (0) peak confirmed that a certain amount of Ni was loaded on NCNT, but no diffraction signal of Ni was found in the XRD diffraction pattern, which was due to the amorphous nature of Ni (0) loaded on the carrier [27]. Table 2 shows the test results of ICP-OES. Comparing the ratio of the theoretical value and the actual value of Pt loading, it can be observed that the changing trend of the total loading rate is similar to that of Pt/NCNT, with a focus on approximately 15 %. However, Pt will be higher in all ratios of Pt and Ni, and when the atomic ratio Pt: Ni=3: 1, the actual loading increased by 1 %, because Ni is more difficult to reduce than Pt [28]. Fig. 5 (A) shows the cyclic voltammetry curves of PtNi alloy catalysts with different proportions of nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes. The highest and second-highest values of current density were measured on Pt3Ni1 and Pt3Ni2, as shown in the figure. It reached 2744mA/mgPt and 2520mA/mgPt, respectively. Pt1Ni1 and Pt2Ni3 are similar, which are 1517mA/mgPt and 1572mA/mgPt, respectively. Pt2Ni1 is 1839mA/mgPt. It can be seen that when the Ni content in the initial feed ratio is the highest, the activity of the catalyst is the lowest. With the increase of the Pt content in the feed ratio, the activity of the catalyst gradually increases. When the feed ratio reaches 3: 1, the activity of the catalyst reaches the maximum value. If the Ni content is increased on this basis, the catalyst's activity will decrease again. This is attributed to the fact that when Pt dominates the surface of the catalyst, the increase in Pt content also increases the active component on the catalyst, resulting in gradual improvement in the catalyst's performance. When the content of Pt is constant, increasing the content of the Ni component will partially cover the surface of Pt, but reduce the active sites on the catalyst's surface. Even if Ni and Pt have a dual-channel mechanism and ligand effect, the Ni component itself hinders methanol oxidation, resulting in a decrease in catalyst activity [29,30]. Fig. 5(B) is the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) test results of PtNi alloy catalysts with different proportions. ECSA is a crucial parameter for evaluating the number of active sites of the catalyst. The ECSA value represents the number of active centers of the catalyst. When the ECSA value is larger, it means that the catalyst has more active centers [8]. The ECSA of the catalyst can be calculated by the equation (eq. (1)). In the formula: [Pt] is the amount of catalyst coated on the surface of glassy carbon electrode, mg/cm2; QH is the average charge calculated according to the adsorption and desorption peaks of hydrogen, mC/cm2; 0.21 is the amount of electricity required to oxidize a monolayer of hydrogen on the Pt surface, mC/cm2. (1() ECSA = Q H / ( [ Pt ] × 0.21 ) The ECSA of Pt2Ni3/NCNT is 1.152cm2/mgPt, the ECSA of Pt1Ni1/NCNT is 4.503cm2/mgPt, the ECSA of Pt2Ni1/NCNT is 12.065cm2/mgPt, the ECSA of Pt3Ni2/NCNT is 13.682cm2/mgPt, and the ECSA of Pt3Ni1/NCNT is 15.108cm2/mgPt. It can be seen that the electrochemical surface area increases with the increase of Pt content. When the Pt content is constant, increasing the Ni content results in a decrease in the ECSA value. This also confirms that the Ni content will affect the electrocatalytic oxidation of methanol by Pt. Table 3 . Fig. 5(C) is the EIS fitting spectrum of PtNi catalysts with different ratios. The low-frequency arc diameters of Pt1Ni1/NCNT and Pt2Ni3/NCNT are the largest, indicating that the two catalysts have the highest charge transfer impedance. This is consistent with the results, as the peak current densities of Pt1Ni1/NCNT and Pt2Ni3/NCNT are similar and the lowest in the cyclic voltammetry curve. The corresponding arc diameters of Pt2Ni1/NCNT and Pt3Ni2/NCNT are 6402 and 5970, respectively. The charge transfer impedance gradually decreases, and the peak current density in the corresponding cyclic voltammetry curve gradually increases. The arc diameter of Pt3Ni1/NCNT is 5359, and the charge transfer impedance is the lowest. The catalyst also shows the highest peak current density in the cyclic voltammetry curve, which is consistent with the results. Combined with Fig. 5(B), Pt3Ni1/NCNT has the largest ECSA surface area and the lowest charge transfer impedance, thereby exhibiting the highest peak current density. The Tafel slope reflects the trend of the electrochemical reaction rate with the overpotential. In Fig. 5(I), Pt3Ni1/NCNT exhibits the smallest Tafel slope, indicating that the kinetic energy barrier of the catalytic reaction is lower, the reaction kinetics is faster, and the intrinsic activity is higher [31]. Fig. 5(D) is the chronoamperometry current curve of PtNi alloy with different proportions loaded on NCNT. One can notice from the diagram that the stability of Pt2Ni3/NCNT is the worst. When the time reaches 1000s, only 173mA/mgPt is left, while Pt3Ni1/NCNT still has a current density of 698 mA/mgPt at 1000s. It is 4.03 times that of Pt2Ni3/NCNT. It is evident from the curve trend in the graph that the current density decreases sharply at the initial stage of the test, which is due to the formation of COads intermediate products that poison the catalyst [37]. The initial potential and decline rate of Pt3Ni1/NCNT are better than those of other catalysts. The results show that among the five catalysts, Pt3Ni1/NCNT exhibits the best stability in the MOR process and demonstrates strong resistance to CO poisoning. Fig. 5(E)- (F) is the CO stripping curve of the commercial Pt/C catalyst and Pt3Ni1/NCNT. From Fig. 5(F), it can be seen that the CO oxidation peak of Pt3Ni1/NCNT appears at-0.266 V, with a peak value of 277.85 mA/mgPt, which is 2.98 times that of commercial Pt/C (93.15 mA/mgPt) and 1.49 times that of Pt/NCNT (186.65 mA/mgPt). It is indicated that Pt3Ni1/NCNT exhibits stronger CO oxidation ability. There is only one weak oxidation peak in the second scan, indicating that COads have been removed from the catalyst surface. The higher CO oxidation peak current may be attributed to the fact that Ni also participates in the reaction as an active site in the catalyst, promoting the activation of water, generating OHads to oxidise COads over time, and facilitating its conversion and desorption from the catalyst surface [38–40]. Fig. 5 (G-F) shows the ADT test curves of commercial Pt/C and Pt3Ni1/NCNT. As can be observed from Fig. 5(F) the peak current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT is 2445.6mA/mgPt, which is reduced to 1708mA/mgPt after 500 cycles, and the remaining 69.83 %. Its peak current density and residual current density are 3.81 times and 9.03 times that of commercial Pt/C, respectively. Compared with the Pt/NCNT catalyst (peak current density 1431 mA/mgPt, remaining 44.46 % after 500 cycles, 636.6mA/mgPt), the Pt/NCNT catalyst showed higher peak current density and better stability [41]. Combined with the test results of Fig. 4(D)- (F), Pt3Ni1/NCNT has the best CO poisoning resistance and the lowest performance decay rate in the same group of catalysts, which is consistent with the decay results shown in the CAs curve in Fig. 5(C). In summary, when Pt: Ni= 3: 1, the performance of the PtNi/NCNT catalyst is the best. At present, we have analyzed the key role of Ni and Pt in the MOR process, expounded the influence of the PtNi ratio on the performance of the catalyst, and proved that alloying can significantly improve the activity and stability of the catalyst. However, the intrinsic relationship between the degree of alloying and MOR performance is still unclear. Therefore, we once again focused on the effect of the PtNi alloying degree on the catalyst's performance and proposed a simple and convenient heat treatment method. Through this method, a PtNi catalyst with a high alloying degree was prepared, supported on NCNT, and labelled Pt3Ni1/NCNT-X. Fig. 6 (B) shows the XRD patterns of the Pt3Ni1/NCNT catalyst after heat treatment at different temperatures. Similar to the PtNi/NCNT mentioned above, no diffraction peaks of elemental Pt and elemental Ni were observed, which again confirmed that the catalyst had a higher 2θ value on the corresponding crystal plane, indicating that the smaller Ni atoms were combined into the lattice of Pt to form a PtNi alloy. The small-sized Ni was squeezed into the lattice of Pt atoms to produce lattice compressive strain. The change of lattice stress and the change of atomic arrangement made the 5d orbital of Pt move down [36]. Pt3Ni1/NCNT alloy catalyst was obtained by heat treatment at 200 °C, 400 °C and 600 °C in H2/Ar atmosphere. One can observe from the magnification diagram in the upper right corner that, with an increase in treatment temperature, the 2θ positive displacement of the catalyst exhibits an apparent increasing trend, and there is no notable shift at 200 °C. When the temperature rises to 400 °C, the Pt (111) crystal plane comes to 2θ= 40.3°, and the (200) crystal plane comes to 2θ= 46.9°, resulting in a positive shift of 0.3° and 0.5°, respectively. When the temperature rises to 600 °C, the (111) crystal plane comes to 2θ= 40.5°, and the Pt (200) crystal plane comes to 47°, resulting in a positive shift of 0.5° and 0.6°, respectively. This means that the high-temperature heat treatment in a hydrogen atmosphere causes the lattice compression strain of the PtNi alloy loaded on the carbon carrier, and the alloy nanoparticles with higher alloying degrees are formed at 600 °C. The higher alloying degree makes Ni provide more electrons to Pt, thus changing the electronic structure of Pt, and the formed mixed d orbital energy is lower than the original 5d orbital energy of Pt [42]. Fig. 6(D) shows that the lattice spacing of Pt (111) crystal plane shrinks to 3.14 Å, which is basically consistent with the lattice spacing of 3.22 Å calculated by Scherrer formula in the direction of Pt (111) crystal plane. Compared with the state in Fig. 2(D), further compression occurs, which directly proves that the annealing treatment leads to the continuous decrease of the lattice constant, reflecting the ordered shrinkage of the unit cell at the atomic level. In addition, with the increase in temperature, the peak shape of the catalyst becomes more acute, and the intensity of the diffraction peak corresponding to the specific crystal plane increases, which indicates that the increase in temperature not only contributes to the growth of PtNi nanocrystals but also makes the PtNi alloy on the surface of the catalyst expose more Pt (111) active surface [43]. Fig. 6(A) is the TEM image of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 after high-temperature heat treatment at 600 °C for 1 h in a 10 % H2/Ar atmosphere. As shown in Figs. 6(A1)- (A3), it can be seen that after heat treatment, although the average grain size remains at 2 nm, there has been obvious agglomeration, and the agglomeration phenomenon is most obvious in the head of carbon nanotubes. It can be seen in the figure that two obvious aggregates are mainly since the CNT head is more easily destroyed during the acid treatment before N doping, resulting in a large number of oxygen-containing functional groups (such as carboxyl groups). The uneven distribution of oxygen-containing functional groups easily leads to the aggregation of Pt particles here. Fig. 6(C) is the mapping image of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600. Compared with Fig. 2(C), we can find that the degree of agglomeration increases after heat treatment, which is due to the dynamic change and mobility of metal particles at high temperatures. In the process of dynamic change of particles, Ostwald ripening [44] and Migrationcoalescence process [45] occur on dispersed nanoparticles, which makes the size of small particles shrink continuously. The size of large particles continues to expand, which aggravates the agglomeration of metal nanoparticles loaded on the catalyst support [46]. In addition, as can be observed from Fig. 6(C3) and Fig. 6(C4) Pt and Ni are still evenly distributed on the tube wall, but there is obvious agglomeration in the head of NCNT, which is consistent with the results of Fig. 6(A). Fig. 6(C1) clearly shows that the corresponding atoms of Pt and Ni on NCNT are stacked together, so that the nanoparticles are superimposed by light blue and green, showing cyan. This stacking is more obvious than the mapping image of Pt3Ni1/NCNT in Fig. 6(C), indicating that Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 has a higher degree of alloying than Pt3Ni1/NCNT, which is consistent with the highest degree of positive shift of 2θ angle of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 in Fig. 6(B). On the other hand, compared with Fig. 1(B4), Fig. 6(C2) shows that the NCNT used in Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is doped with more N. It shows that in the process of direct pyrolysis doping, the nitrogen source has not yet reached a completely uniform distribution state, which makes the difference between different concentrations of N doped in the same batch of carriers [40,47]. Fig. 3(C) is the Pt 4f orbital fine spectrum of the catalyst after heat treatment under different temperature conditions in a hydrogen atmosphere. From the graph, it can be found that the Pt (0) 4f7/2 peak begins to shift positively with the increase in the treatment temperature. Combined with Table 5, it can be seen that when the treatment temperatures are 200 °C, 400 °C, and 600 °C, Pt (0) 4f7/2 exhibits 0.02 eV, 0.1 eV, and 0.45 eV positive shifts, respectively. The content of Pt (0) in Table 4 shows that the content of Pt (0) in the catalyst increases with the increase of heat treatment temperature, and the content of Pt (0) in Pt nanoparticles will significantly affect the MOR activity of the catalyst [16]. When the heat treatment temperature reaches 600 °C, the Pt (0) content in the Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 catalyst reaches 67.01 %, which is consistent with the highest catalytic activity of the catalyst in the CVs curve. The positive shift of binding energy in Pt atoms also represents the downward shift of the Pt d band center. Combined with the influence of lattice compression strain and alloying degree on 5d orbital in XRD analysis, the three factors work together to weaken the electron transfer between Pt 5d orbital and CO 2p* orbital, thus weakening the bond energy of CO-Pt and enhancing the stability of the catalyst [48,49]. This also corresponds to the results that Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 exhibits the best stability in the CAs curve. Figs. 3(D) is the fine spectra of Ni 2p orbitals after heat treatment at different temperatures in the hydrogen atmosphere. It can be seen from the figure that with the increase in treatment temperature, the position of Ni (II) 2p3/2 peak in the catalyst shows a negative shift. Combined with Table 5 , it was found that when the treatment temperature reached 200 °C, 400 °C, and 600 °C, Ni (II) 2p3/2 produced negative shifts of −0.01 eV, −0.07 eV, and−0.2 eV, respectively. From the Ni (II) content in Table 4, it can be seen that the Ni (II) content gradually increases with the increase of the treatment temperature, and reaches a maximum of 49.69 % at the treatment temperature of 600 °C. This indicates that when the heat treatment temperature increases, more Ni components enter the Pt atoms, and these low-valent Ni provide electrons to the high-valent Pt, increasing the content of Pt (0) in the Pt nanoparticles on the catalyst surface, thereby improving the MOR performance of the catalyst. It is worth noting that in the system of high temperature heat treatment in 10 % hydrogen atmosphere, Ni2+is not significantly reduced to metal Ni0, but shows the correlation between the peak value of Ni2+ content and the optimal catalytic performance. This is because, in the low-temperature region (200 °C), the activation energy of hydrogen molecules is insufficient, the alloying process is slow, and Ni2+ is mainly distributed on the surface of the nanoparticles. At this time, the surface Ni2+ is prone to a heterogeneous reduction reaction with hydrogen; however, the degree of alloying at this temperature is low, and the Pt active site does not form an effective electronic regulation, resulting in poor catalytic performance. In the high-temperature region, although the hydrogen reduction ability increases with temperature, the lattice reconstruction driven by alloying is dominant. In this structure, the 3d orbital of Ni2+ is hybridized with the 5d orbital of Pt, which makes the reduction potential of Ni2+ shift positively and is more difficult to be reduced thermodynamically [50]. In Table 4, we also found that when the catalyst was not treated, it was found that the Ni (II) content in the catalyst was 33.16 %, which was higher than 23.27 % after 200 °C treatment and 27.02 % after 400 °C treatment, but the content of Pt (0) did not increase accordingly, which was the lowest 43.18 %. The possible reason is that some Ni in the catalyst without treatment exists in the form of Ni (II) alone on the carrier, and does not form an alloy with Pt. With the increase of treatment temperature, this part of Ni becomes other higher valence Ni, and then gradually forms an alloy [50,51]; with the rise of alloy content, stable Ni (II) is slowly formed, so that Ni (II) reaches the highest value when the treatment temperature reaches 600 °C. Fig. 7 (A) shows the CV curves of Pt3Ni1/NCNT, Pt3Ni1/NCNT-200, Pt3Ni1/NCNT-400, and Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600. As shown in the figure, Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 exhibits the highest MOR peak current density and far exceeds other catalysts, reaching 4504mA/mgPt, which is higher than 2503mA/mgPt of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-400 and 2067 mA/mgPt of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-200, far higher than 1263mA/mgPt of Pt3Ni1/NCNT, which is 7.73 times that of commercial Pt/C (about 582mA/mgPt). Fig. 7(B) shows the ECSA test results of the catalyst treated at different temperatures. As shown in the figure, as the temperature gradually increases, the electrochemical surface area also gradually increases. When the heat treatment temperature reaches 600 °C, the maximum electrochemical surface area is obtained, which conforms to the growth trend of the peak value of the CVs curve in Fig. 7(A). Table 6 shows the lattice constant and ECSA value of the catalyst-supported alloy at different temperatures. It can be seen that as the treatment temperature increases, the lattice constant decreases, and the ECSA of the corresponding catalyst increases. At the same time, it shows that more Ni enters into the Pt atom. With the increase of the content of Ni component in the Pt atom, more low-valent Ni provides electrons to the high-valent Pt, increasing the content of Pt (0) in the catalyst, thereby increasing the electrochemical surface area. It is consistent with the performance of Pt and Ni fine spectra in XPS test results. On the whole, in the CV test, compared with other catalysts, Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 has the highest peak current density the largest electrochemical surface area, and the smallest lattice constant. This indicates that the Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 catalyst has the highest MOR activity and lattice compression degree [52,53]. Fig. 7(C) presents the EIS curve fitting diagram of the catalyst after heat treatment at different temperatures. As shown in the figure, the arc radius of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-200 is 3477, which is lower than that of the untreated Pt3Ni1/NCNT, indicating that the charge transfer impedance of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-200 decreases after heat treatment. However, the catalyst exhibits a diffusion impedance in the high-frequency region, and the linear trend is close to the X-axis, indicating that the ion transfer rate of the catalyst in the electrolyte is very slow [26,54]. The arc radii of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-400 and Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 were significantly lower than those of the untreated catalyst and the catalyst heat-treated at 200 °C, which were 2503 and 1589, respectively. The charge transfer impedance of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is notably lower than that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT, and the peak current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 in the CVs curve is much higher than that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT. The decreasing trend of the EIS curve indicates that the charge transfer impedance of the catalyst gradually decreases as the heat treatment temperature increases. This may be attributed to the increase in the alloying degree of the metal nanoparticles in the catalyst after heat treatment. As the temperature rises, the degree of alloying gradually increases, the charge transfer impedance decreases, and the ECSA value increases. Consequently, the peak current density in the CVs curve also increases, showing a trend of rising with the increase in temperature [55]. At the same time, the Tafel slope was measured in Fig. 7I. It can be observed that the catalyst treated at 600 °C has the smallest slope, indicating that the reaction energy barrier is significantly reduced during the electrocatalytic process, resulting in the lowest kinetic barrier and the best electrocatalytic kinetic performance. Fig. 7(D) is the chronoamperometry current curve of the Pt3Ni1/NCNT-X catalyst in 1.0 M KOH + 1.0 M CH3OH solution. It can be seen that when untreated, the current density of the catalyst decreased sharply within 150 min and then stabilised. This is due to the double-layer charging current generated by the potential jump at the initial stage of the test. The instantaneous potential of the current is large but the decay rate is extremely fast, resulting in a sharp decline in the initial stage of the timing current curve [56]. With the attenuation of the electric double-layer current, a stable electric double-layer structure is gradually formed to achieve steady-state polarization. The steady-state current after steady-state polarization represents the steady-state electrocatalytic oxidation rate of methanol at this potential. With the increase in treatment temperature, the initial sharp decline trend gradually slowed down, and the slowing trend of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 was the most obvious. When it reached 3600 s, Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 still had a current density of 497.65mA/mgPt, which was 14.47 times that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT (34.38mA/mgPt). This shows that the catalyst after heat treatment at 600 °C is higher than other catalysts in MOR rate and anti-poisoning ability [57]. Fig. 7(E) - (F) shows the CO dissolution curves of Pt3Ni1/NCNT and Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600. It is evident from Fig. 7(F) that the CO oxidation peak value of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is 433.7 mA/mgPt, which appears at the position of 0.257 V. In the second round of scanning, there is only one, and it's a weak CO oxidation peak. Compared with the CO oxidation peak of Pt3Ni1/NCNT in Fig. 7(E), the CO oxidation peak current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is 1.56 times that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT (277.85mA/mgPt), and the CO oxidation peak potential is less than-0.266 V of Pt3Ni1/NCNT, indicating that Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 catalyst has stronger oxidation ability for CO and the CO adsorption energy on the surface is lower than that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT, which is easier to be removed from the catalyst surface. This is consistent with the test results that the current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is still much larger than that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT after 3600 s in the chronoamperometry curve. Fig. 7(G) is the ADT curve of Pt3Ni1/NCNT and Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600, and Fig. 7(H) is the ADT curve of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600. As is visible from the two figures the peak current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is 4253mA/mgPt, which is 1.74 times that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT (2445.6mA/mgPt). After 500 cycles, the current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is reduced to 3683mA/mgPt, which is 2.15 times that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT (1708mA/mgPt). The current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 after 500 cycles is 86.59 % of the peak current density, which is higher than 69.83 % of Pt3Ni1/NCNT. The ADT test results show that Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is superior to Pt3Ni1/NCNT in both peak current density and decay rate, showing better electrocatalytic activity and stability [53]. After the ADT test, the catalyst was subjected to secondary characterisation to analyse its structural and compositional evolution. As shown in Fig. 8 (A) Pt3Ni1/NCNT XRD pattern, the intensity of the characteristic diffraction peaks of Pt (JCPDS # 04–0802) and Ni (JCPDS # 65–9445) decreased significantly after the reaction, suggesting that the crystallinity or content of the metal active phase was lost [58]. The similar trend is also seen in the XRD spectrum of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 in Fig. 8(D), and it is worth noting that the diffraction peak intensity of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is higher than that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT before and after the reaction, indicating that the annealing treatment enhances the crystalline integrity of the metal phase. The HRTEM image and the particle size distribution histogram (Fig. 8B, C correspond to Pt3Ni1/NCNT, Fig. 8E, F correspond to Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600) further reveal that the metal particles of fresh Pt3Ni1/NCNT are uniformly dispersed with an average particle size of about 2.1 nm. After 500 cycles, although the carbon nanotube skeleton retains its complete morphology, the metal particles are agglomerated, the particle size distribution is broadened, and the average particle size increases to ∼ 5.6 nm. In contrast, the average particle size of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 increased to only 4.5 nm after reaction, indicating a lighter degree of deterioration. This difference is due to the electrochemical stress generated by the potential cycle during the ADT process, which makes the small particles with higher surface energy more likely to dissolve the metal atoms, and the dissolved species redeposit on the surface of the large particles. The Ostwald ripening mechanism drives particle coarsening and annealing-induced strong metal-support interaction, which effectively inhibits the dissolution and migration of small particles [44]. Combined with ICP-OES quantitative analysis (Table 7 ), it can be seen that the metal loading of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 (17.95 wt. %) is slightly higher than that of unannealed Pt3Ni1/NCNT (16.41 wt. %) in the fresh state. The reason is that the metals in the unannealed samples are mostly loaded in the form of oxidized precursors. When annealed at 600 °C and 10 % H2/Ar atmosphere, the reduction reaction will remove the oxygen element in the form of H2O [59], and the total mass of the catalyst will decrease, while the absolute mass of Pt and Ni is not lost. Therefore, the loading of 'metal mass/total catalyst mass' will increase passively due to the decrease of denominator. Similarly, the effective loading rate of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 (89.75 %) is also higher than that of the unannealed sample (82.05 %), confirming that the annealing treatment enhances the binding efficiency of the metal and the carrier. After the ADT test (Used), the metal loading of the two types of samples showed a downward trend, Pt3Ni1/NCNT decreased to 10.89 wt. %, Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 decreased to 14.96 wt. %. This is due to the electrochemical stress caused by the potential cycle during the ADT process, which causes the dissolution of the metal surface and directly leads to the reduction of the absolute mass of Pt and Ni; at the same time, the dissolved metal atoms redeposit on the surface of the large particles through the Ostwald ripening mechanism, driving the agglomeration of the particles. Although the agglomeration is accompanied by the mass migration of ‘small particle dissolution-large particle deposition’, the decrease of ICP loading indicates that the dissolved metal is not completely re-precipitated and partially lost from the catalyst system, which eventually leads to the simultaneous decrease of the total mass and mass ratio of the metal [60]. In particular, it is worth noting that the attenuation of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 (16.6 %) is significantly lower than that of Pt3Ni1/NCNT (29.9 %), which further proves that the annealing-enhanced metal-support interaction effectively inhibits the electrochemical dissolution and particle coarsening. To determine the reaction path of methanol electrocatalytic oxidation under the Pt electrocatalytic system and analyze the influence mechanism of Ni on methanol conversion, we used in-situ infrared spectroscopy to capture the key intermediate species of methanol electrocatalytic oxidation. The schematic diagram of the device is shown in Fig. 9 (A). Fig. 9(B) is the FT-IR spectrum of Pt/NCNT, and a linear CO (COL) band at 2151 cm-1 can be observed, indicating that CO intermediates are generated during MOR, and the band near 2341 cm-1 is attributed to the gas phase of CO2, indicating that CO is finally oxidized to CO2. Fig. 9(C) is the FT-IR spectrum of Pt3Ni1/NCNT. As shown in the figure, at the beginning of the reaction, some new absorption bands begin to appear in the spectrum. The band at 1669 cm−1 can be assigned to the deformation of water [61]. The band located at 2170 cm-1 COL also indicates that CO intermediates are involved in the MOR process. However, compared with the characteristic peak of linear CO (COL) in Pt/NCNT catalyst, the characteristic peak of linear CO (COL) corresponding to Pt3Ni1/NCNT catalyst is higher, indicating that under the same conditions, Pt3Ni1/NCNT electrocatalytic MOR produces more CO and MOR rate is faster. In particular, we found characteristic peaks belonging to formate at 1351 cm-1,1381 cm-1, and 1565 cm-1, indicating the formation of formate in the reaction, confirming the existence of methanol oxidation in Pt-based catalysts. There are two paths, and there is a kinetic rate competition between the two paths, which further reduces the possibility of catalyst poisoning by reducing the formation of COads. In addition, the CO2 band near 2340 cm-1 is higher, which is attributed to the introduction of Ni reduces the d-band center of Pt and promotes the further oxidation of CO, and MOR occurs on Pt3Ni1/NCNT with the formation of water, which conforms to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism of CO reduction. The d-band center of Pt is regulated by Ni alloying on this surface, which alleviates the adsorption-desorption of reactants and intermediates, accelerates electron transfer, promotes the cleavage of CH bond at low potential, and enhances the MOR kinetics [62]. At the same time, the presence of Ni promotes the activation/dissociation of H2O in an alkaline electrolyte, and the activity (OHads) is generated by the higher oxygen affinity of Ni than Pt, thereby generating sufficient oxygen species to increase MOR (CH3OH+ 8OH-→ CO3 2- + 6H2O + 6e-), generating OHads species to allow oxidative removal of intermediates, thereby protecting the active site of Pt from poisoning [56]. The electronic effect and synergistic effect driven by PtNi alloy are beneficial to the bifunctional mechanism, that is, with the assistance of adjacent OHads adsorbed on PtNi, the intermediate products COads and HCOOads are rapidly oxidized to CO2, thus accelerating the MOR kinetics and improving the durability, the reaction process is shown in Fig. 9(D) - (E). The MOR mechanism proposed on PtNi can be described as follows: (2) Pt + CH3OH→ Pt-(CH3OH)ads (3) Ni-O + H2O+2e-→Ni + 2OH- (4) Ni + OH-→Ni-(OH-)ads (5) Pt-(CH3OH)ads + 5Ni-(OH-)ads→Pt-(HCOO-)ads + 5Ni + 4H2O + 4e- (6) Pt-(HCOO-) ads + Ni- OH ads+ Pt-(CO2) ads +Ni+H2O+2 e - (7) Pt-(CO2)ads→ Pt + CO2 To further delve into the influence mechanism of Ni on the methanol oxidation performance of the Pt catalyst system, the Pt3Ni1/NCNT and Pt/NCNT catalyst models were constructed through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Subsequently, an in-depth analysis was conducted on the internal causes underlying the catalyst's resistance to CO poisoning. The results are presented as shown in Fig. 10 . The different reaction mechanisms of MOR on Pt (111) and Pt3Ni1 (111) surfaces were explored and compared. By calculating the hydrogen electrode model, the Gibbs free energy [63,64] of all the basic steps along the reaction coordinate is studied. On Pt(111) and Pt3Ni1 (111) surfaces, CH3OH exhibits two different sequential dehydrogenation processes (CH3OHads → CH2OHads → CHOHads → COHads → COads and CH3OHads → CH3Oads → CH2Oads → H2COOHads → COOHads), resulting in the production of COads and COOHads, which we call CO path and HCOOH path. COads will further interact with the hydroxyl (OHads) group produced by electrolytic water and convert into CO2, and COOHads will further dehydrogenate into CO2. Here, it is reflected as ΔG< 0. From the reaction coordinates, on the Pt (111)surface, the rate-limiting step (RLS) is COads → COads + OHads, the free energy change is 1.14 eV, and the highly stable COads have the most negative free energy. The highest COads activation barrier of strong intermediate binding on Pt (111) was observed, which is a reasonable explanation for its poor stability and tolerance. On Pt3Ni1 (111) surface, RLS is CHOHads → COHads and H2COOHads → HCOOHads, and the energy changes are 1.18 eV and 0.85 eV, respectively. Compared with the RLS of (COads → COads + OHads) with a free energy change of 1.14 eV on the Pt (111)surface, the RLS of the CO path on the Pt3Ni1 (111)surface has a higher energy barrier, which is not conducive to thermodynamics and inhibits the CO path, while the RLS in the HCOOH path is lower than the free energy change of the Pt (111) surface, which is beneficial to thermodynamics. In summary, the above calculation evidence shows that the introduction of Ni atoms can adjust the binding energy of the intermediate and the rate-limiting step of the reaction, enhance the reaction kinetics, and ultimately improve the activity, stability, and CO poisoning resistance of MOR. Consistent with the reported studies, Pt3Ni1 alloy catalyst can produce two competitive reaction paths in MOR, inhibit the CO path to a certain extent, promote the HCOOH path, reduce the production of COads, reduce the possibility of catalyst poisoning, improve the stability of the catalyst, and increase the activation energy barrier of CO, so that the reaction passes through the lower activation energy barrier of HCOOH to improve the kinetics of methanol electrocatalytic oxidation. 4 Conclusions In this paper, Pt3Ni1/NCNT-X alloy catalysts were prepared by a one-step hydrothermal method and co-reduction method in a 10 % H2/Ar atmosphere. Through serial characterization methods such as XRD, XPS, and TEM, it is found that Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 has the highest alloying degree. The increase of Ni content promotes more Ni atoms to provide electrons to Pt, further increases the content of Pt (0), reduces the charge transfer impedance, and then increases the active sites of the catalytic MOR process. The electrochemical performance test shows that the MOR activity and stability of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 that is heat-treated have been significantly improved. By analyzing the XPS spectrum, it is verified that with the increase of heat treatment temperature, the peak position of Pt 4f7/2 has a positive shift, which indicates that the d-band center of Pt moves down. The peak current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 reached 4504 mA/mgPt. When the test time was increased from 1000 s to 3600 s, the current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 still reached 497.65 mA/mgPt, which was 14.47 times that of the untreated Pt3Ni1/NCNT catalyst. In the CO dissolution curve, Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 had a higher CO oxidation peak than Pt3Ni1/NCNT in the first scan, and only a very weak oxidation peak in the second scan. It shows that Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 has stronger resistance to CO poisoning. In the ADT curve, the residual current density of Pt3Ni1/NCNT-600 is 86.59 % of the peak current density after 500 cycles. The test results of the CO dissolution curve and ADT curve are consistent with the test results of the CAs curve. Finally, the presence of formate in the reaction process was proved by in-situ infrared spectroscopy, the result shows that two reaction pathways of MOR occur competitively under the action of PtNi alloy. DFT theoretical calculations confirmed that PtNi alloy particles provided a higher potential for OHads oxidation COads to inhibit COads formation, and a lower potential to promote HCOOads oxidation to CO2. Thus, most of the reaction process bypasses the CO pathmaking, the CO poisoning of the electrocatalytic process was reduced and the overall kinetics of MOR was improved effectually. In general, the work carried out in this paper provides a new perspective for the design of high-performance electrocatalysts by exploring new hybrid materials. coredata.dc:description: Methanol dehydrogenation occurs at the Pt-solution interface. Thermodynamically unstable nanocrystals on the catalyst surface cause intermediate toxic COads, poisoning and deactivating the catalyst. N-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNT) were made using melamine. PtNi/NCNT electrocatalysts were prepared by a hydrothermal-H2/Ar reduction one-step process. Their microstructure and properties were analyzed. The electrochemical performance of PtNi alloy catalysts was measured with MOR as a probe. The excellent performance is due to Ni introduction and its synergy with Pt nanoparticles. The electrocatalytic oxidation pathways of methanol on Pt/NCNT and PtNi/NCNT were studied by an in - situ platform. Methanol is converted via the HCOOH pathway and CO pathway simultaneously. DFT calculations confirm the Ni doping mechanism. Ni doping changes methanol dehydrogenation position, making the CO and formate paths competitive, avoiding CO poisoning of Pt active sites. In - situ infrared and CO poisoning experiments confirm these, providing ideas for Pt electrocatalyst design.
